I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sad, lady! I could be sad: this does make some
obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering; but
what of that? if it please the eye of one, it is
with me as the very true sonnet is, 'Please one, and
please all.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Why, how dost thou, man? what is the matter with thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It
did come to his hands, and commands shall be
executed: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: To bed! ay, sweet-heart, and I'll come to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so and kiss
thy hand so oft?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: How do you, Malvolio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: At your request! yes; nightingales answer daws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'Be not afraid of greatness:' 'twas well writ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'Some are born great,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Ha!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'Some achieve greatness,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: What sayest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'And some have greatness thrust upon them.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Heaven restore thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'Remember who commended thy yellow stockings,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Thy yellow stockings!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'And wished to see thee cross-gartered.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Cross-gartered!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'Go to thou art made, if thou desirest to be so;'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Am I made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: 'If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Why, this is very midsummer madness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
LINE: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's is
returned: I could hardly entreat him back: he
attends your ladyship's pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: I'll come to him.
Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's
my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special
care of him: I would not have him miscarry for the
half of my dowry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: O, ho! do you come near me now? no worse man than
Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly with
the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may
appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that
in the letter. 'Cast thy humble slough,' says she;
'be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants;
let thy tongue tang with arguments of state; put
thyself into the trick of singularity;' and
consequently sets down the manner how; as, a sad
face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the
habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have
limed her; but it is Jove's doing, and Jove make me
thankful! And when she went away now, 'Let this
fellow be looked to:' fellow! not Malvolio, nor
after my degree, but fellow. Why, every thing
adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no
scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous
or unsafe circumstance--What can be said? Nothing
that can be can come between me and the full
prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the
doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all
the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion
himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir?
how is't with you, man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy my private: go
off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! did not
I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a
care of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Ah, ha! does she so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Go to, go to; peace, peace; we must deal gently
with him: let me alone. How do you, Malvolio? how
is't with you? What, man! defy the devil:
consider, he's an enemy to mankind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Do you know what you say?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes
it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Carry his water to the wise woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow morning, if I
live. My lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: How now, mistress!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: O Lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not the way: do
you not see you move him? let me alone with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: No way but gentleness; gently, gently: the fiend is
rough, and will not be roughly used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Why, how now, my bawcock! how dost thou, chuck?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sir!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Ay, Biddy, come with me. What, man! 'tis not for
gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan: hang
him, foul collier!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: My prayers, minx!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle shallow
things: I am not of your element: you shall know
more hereafter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Is't possible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: If this were played upon a stage now, I could
condemn it as an improbable fiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: The house will be the quieter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound. My
niece is already in the belief that he's mad: we
may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance,
till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt
us to have mercy on him: at which time we will
bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a
finder of madmen. But see, but see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: More matter for a May morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Here's the challenge, read it: warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Is't so saucy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Ay, is't, I warrant him: do but read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Give me.
'Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Good, and valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH

LINE.__text: 'Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind,

LINE: why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for't.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: A good note; that keeps you from the blow of the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH

LINE.__text: 'Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my

LINE: sight she uses thee kindly: but thou liest in thy
throat; that is not the matter I challenge thee for.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense--less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH

LINE.__text: 'I will waylay thee going home; where if it

LINE: be thy chance to kill me,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Good.

LINE.__text: 'Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law: good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH

LINE.__text: 'Fare thee well; and God have mercy upon

LINE: one of our souls! He may have mercy upon mine; but
my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy
friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK.
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot:
I'll give't him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: You may have very fit occasion for't: he is now in
some commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Go, Sir Andrew: scout me for him at the corner the
orchard like a bum-baily: so soon as ever thou seest
him, draw; and, as thou drawest swear horrible; for
it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a
swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood
more approbation than ever proof itself would have
earned him. Away!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Now will not I deliver his letter: for the behavior
of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good
capacity and breeding; his employment between his
lord and my niece confirms no less: therefore this
letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no
terror in the youth: he will find it comes from a
clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by
word of mouth; set upon Aguecheek a notable report
of valour; and drive the gentleman, as I know his
youth will aptly receive it, into a most hideous
opinion of his rage, skill, fury and impetuosity.
This will so fright them both that they will kill
one another by the look, like cockatrices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Here he comes with your niece: give them way till
he take leave, and presently after him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message
for a challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honour too unchary out:
There's something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mocks reproof.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: With the same 'havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture;
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honour saved may upon asking give?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Nothing but this; your true love for my master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: How with mine honour may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I will acquit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Well, come again to-morrow: fare thee well:
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Gentleman, God save thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: And you, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: That defence thou hast, betake thee to't: of what
nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know
not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as
the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end:
dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for
thy assailant is quick, skilful and deadly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any quarrel
to me: my remembrance is very free and clear from
any image of offence done to any man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: You'll find it otherwise, I assure you: therefore,
if you hold your life at any price, betake you to
your guard; for your opposite hath in him what
youth, strength, skill and wrath can furnish man withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I pray you, sir, what is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on
carpet consideration; but he is a devil in private
brawl: souls and bodies hath he divorced three; and
his incensement at this moment is so implacable,
that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death
and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word; give't or take't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I will return again into the house and desire some
conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard
of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on
others, to taste their valour: belike this is a man
of that quirk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a
very competent injury: therefore, get you on and
give him his desire. Back you shall not to the
house, unless you undertake that with me which with
as much safety you might answer him: therefore, on,
or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle you
must, that's certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me
this courteous office, as to know of the knight what
my offence to him is: it is something of my
negligence, nothing of my purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this
gentleman till my return.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a
mortal arbitrement; but nothing of the circumstance more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by
his form, as you are like to find him in the proof
of his valour. He is, indeed, sir, the most skilful,
bloody and fatal opposite that you could possibly
have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk
towards him? I will make your peace with him if I
can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I shall be much bound to you for't: I am one that
had rather go with sir priest than sir knight: I
care not who knows so much of my mettle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Why, man, he's a very devil; I have not seen such a
firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard and
all, and he gives me the stuck in with such a mortal
motion, that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he
pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they
step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Ay, but he will not now be pacified: Fabian can
scarce hold him yonder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Plague on't, an I thought he had been valiant and so
cunning in fence, I'ld have seen him damned ere I'ld
have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip,
and I'll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: I'll make the motion: stand here, make a good show
on't: this shall end without the perdition of souls.
Marry, I'll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
I have his horse to take up the quarrel:
I have persuaded him the youth's a devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants and
looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH

LINE.__text: There's no remedy, sir; he will fight

LINE: with you for's oath sake: marry, he hath better
bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now
scarce to be worth talking of: therefore draw, for
the supportance of his vow; he protests he will not hurt you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA

LINE.__text: Pray God defend me! A little thing would

LINE: make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Give ground, if you see him furious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman
will, for his honour's sake, have one bout with you;
he cannot by the duello avoid it: but he has
promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he
will not hurt you. Come on; to't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Pray God, he keep his oath!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I do assure you, 'tis against my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: You, sir! why, what are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: O good Sir Toby, hold! here come the officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: I'll be with you anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Marry, will I, sir; and, for that I promised you,
I'll be as good as my word: he will bear you easily
and reins well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
LINE: This is the man; do thy office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
LINE: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: You do mistake me, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
LINE: No, sir, no jot; I know your favour well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away: he knows I know him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: I must obey.
This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed;
But be of comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
LINE: Come, sir, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: I must entreat of you some of that money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show'd me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something: my having is not much;
I'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there's half my coffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Will you deny me now?
Is't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: I know of none;
Nor know I you by voice or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: O heavens themselves!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Officer
LINE: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
LINE: What's that to us? The time goes by: away!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: But O how vile an idol proves this god
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind;
None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind:
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourish'd by the devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
LINE: The man grows mad: away with him! Come, come, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Lead me on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself: so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian: we'll
whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: He named Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favour was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than
a hare: his dishonesty appears in leaving his
friend here in necessity and denying him; and for
his cowardship, ask Fabian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Do; cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: An I do not,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Come, let's see the event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I.  Before OLIVIA's house.
STAGEDIR: Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow:
Let me be clear of thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not know you; nor
I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come
speak with her; nor your name is not Master Cesario;
nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that is so is so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else: Thou
know'st not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Vent my folly! he has heard that word of some
great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my
folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world,
will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy
strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my
lady: shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me: There's
money for thee: if you tarry longer, I shall give
worse payment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men
that give fools money get themselves a good
report--after fourteen years' purchase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Now, sir, have I met you again? there's for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Why, there's for thee, and there, and there. Are all
the people mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger o'er the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: This will I tell my lady straight: I would not be
in some of your coats for two pence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Come on, sir; hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: Nay, let him alone: I'll go another way to work
with him; I'll have an action of battery against
him, if there be any law in Illyria: though I
struck him first, yet it's no matter for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Let go thy hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young
soldier, put up your iron: you are well fleshed; come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: I will be free from thee. What wouldst thou now? If
thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two
of this malapert blood from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Hold, Toby; on thy life I charge thee, hold!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Madam!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne'er were preach'd! out of my sight!
Be not offended, dear Cesario.
Rudesby, be gone!
I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and thou unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botch'd up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this: thou shalt not choose but go:
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
STAGEDIR: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: What relish is in this? how runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream:
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Nay, come, I prithee; would thou'ldst be ruled by me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Madam, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: O, say so, and so be!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II.  OLIVIA's house.
STAGEDIR: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard;
make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate: do
it quickly; I'll call Sir Toby the whilst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself
in't; and I would I were the first that ever
dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to
become the function well, nor lean enough to be
thought a good student; but to be said an honest man
and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a
careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for, as the old hermit of
Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily
said to a niece of King Gorboduc, 'That that is is;'
so I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson; for,
what is 'that' but 'that,' and 'is' but 'is'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: To him, Sir Topas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: What, ho, I say! peace in this prison!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: The knave counterfeits well; a good knave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio
the lunatic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest thou this man!
talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Well said, Master Parson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged: good Sir
Topas, do not think I am mad: they have laid me
here in hideous darkness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most
modest terms; for I am one of those gentle ones
that will use the devil himself with courtesy:
sayest thou that house is dark?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: As hell, Sir Topas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Why it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes,
and the clearstores toward the south north are as
lustrous as ebony; and yet complainest thou of
obstruction?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: I am not mad, Sir Topas: I say to you, this house is dark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Madman, thou errest: I say, there is no darkness
but ignorance; in which thou art more puzzled than
the Egyptians in their fog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though
ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say, there
was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you
are: make the trial of it in any constant question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wild fowl?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness:
thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will
allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock, lest
thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Nay, I am for all waters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARIA
LINE: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and
gown: he sees thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how
thou findest him: I would we were well rid of this
knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I
would he were, for I am now so far in offence with
my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this
sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: 'Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how thy lady does.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: 'My lady is unkind, perdy.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: 'Alas, why is she so?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool, I say!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: 'She loves another'--Who calls, ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my
hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink and paper:
as I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to
thee for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Master Malvolio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Ay, good fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I
am as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: But as well? then you are mad indeed, if you be no
better in your wits than a fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: They have here propertied me; keep me in darkness,
send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to
face me out of my wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Advise you what you say; the minister is here.
Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore!
endeavour thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain
bibble babble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Sir Topas!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Maintain no words with him, good fellow. Who, I,
sir? not I, sir. God be wi' you, good Sir Topas.
Merry, amen. I will, sir, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am
shent for speaking to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper: I
tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Well-a-day that you were, sir

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper and
light; and convey what I will set down to my lady:
it shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing
of letter did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: I will help you to't. But tell me true, are you
not mad indeed? or do you but counterfeit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Believe me, I am not; I tell thee true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I see his
brains. I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Fool, I'll requite it in the highest degree: I
prithee, be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I'll be with you again,
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who, with dagger of lath,
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! to the devil:
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad;
Adieu, good man devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: This is the air; that is the glorious sun;
This pearl she gave me, I do feel't and see't;
And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet 'tis not madness. Where's Antonio, then?
I could not find him at the Elephant:
Yet there he was; and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service;
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad
Or else the lady's mad; yet, if 'twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs and their dispatch
With such a smooth, discreet and stable bearing
As I perceive she does: there's something in't
That is deceiveable. But here the lady comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,
Now go with me and with this holy man
Into the chantry by: there, before him,
And underneath that consecrated roof,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith;
That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
May live at peace. He shall conceal it
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keep
According to my birth. What do you say?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: I'll follow this good man, and go with you;
And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine,
That they may fairly note this act of mine!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I.  Before OLIVIA's house.
STAGEDIR: Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and Lords
Exeunt Clown, FABIAN, SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Do not desire to see this letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: This is, to give a dog, and in recompense desire my
dog again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Ay, sir; we are some of her trappings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: I know thee well; how dost thou, my good fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse
for my friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Just the contrary; the better for thy friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: No, sir, the worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: How can that be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me;
now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass: so that by
my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself,
and by my friends, I am abused: so that,
conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives
make your two affirmatives why then, the worse for
my friends and the better for my foes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Why, this is excellent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: By my troth, sir, no; though it please you to be
one of my friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there's gold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would
you could make it another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: O, you give me ill counsel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once,
and let your flesh and blood obey it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a
double-dealer: there's another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play; and the old
saying is, the third pays for all: the triplex,
sir, is a good tripping measure; or the bells of
Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind; one, two, three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw:
if you will let your lady know I am here to speak
with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake
my bounty further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come
again. I go, sir; but I would not have you to think
that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness:
but, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I
will awake it anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: That face of his I do remember well;
Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmear'd
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war:
A bawbling vessel was he captain of,
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable;
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
That very envy and the tongue of loss
Cried fame and honour on him. What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Officer
LINE: Orsino, this is that Antonio
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy;
And this is he that did the Tiger board,
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg:
Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In private brabble did we apprehend him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side;
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me:
I know not what 'twas but distraction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Notable pirate! thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,
Hast made thine enemies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Orsino, noble sir,
Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me:
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,
Though I confess, on base and ground enough,
Orsino's enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingrateful boy there by your side,
From the rude sea's enraged and foamy mouth
Did I redeem; a wreck past hope he was:
His life I gave him and did thereto add
My love, without retention or restraint,
All his in dedication; for his sake
Did I expose myself, pure for his love,
Into the danger of this adverse town;
Drew to defend him when he was beset:
Where being apprehended, his false cunning,
Not meaning to partake with me in danger,
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twenty years removed thing
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse,
Which I had recommended to his use
Not half an hour before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: How can this be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: When came he to this town?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: To-day, my lord; and for three months before,
No interim, not a minute's vacancy,
Both day and night did we keep company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Here comes the countess: now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee, fellow; fellow, thy words are madness:
Three months this youth hath tended upon me;
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Madam!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Gracious Olivia,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Still so cruel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Still so constant, lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: What, to perverseness? you uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull'st offerings hath breathed out
That e'er devotion tender'd! What shall I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,
Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love?--a savage jealousy
That sometimes savours nobly. But hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favour,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still;
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master's spite.
Come, boy, with me; my thoughts are ripe in mischief:
I'll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven's heart within a dove.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: And I, most jocund, apt and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Where goes Cesario?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Ay me, detested! how am I beguiled!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Hast thou forgot thyself? is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Come, away!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Husband!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Ay, husband: can he that deny?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Her husband, sirrah!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: No, my lord, not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety:
Fear not, Cesario; take thy fortunes up;
Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear'st.
O, welcome, father!
Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,
Here to unfold, though lately we intended
To keep in darkness what occasion now
Reveals before 'tis ripe, what thou dost know
Hath newly pass'd between this youth and me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Priest
LINE: A contract of eternal bond of love,
Confirm'd by mutual joinder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lips,
Strengthen'd by interchangement of your rings;
And all the ceremony of this compact
Seal'd in my function, by my testimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell'd but two hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: O thou dissembling cub! what wilt thou be
When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow,
That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet
Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: My lord, I do protest--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: O, do not swear!
Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently
to Sir Toby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby
a bloody coxcomb too: for the love of God, your
help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: The count's gentleman, one Cesario: we took him for
a coward, but he's the very devil incardinate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: My gentleman, Cesario?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: 'Od's lifelings, here he is! You broke my head for
nothing; and that that I did, I was set on to do't
by Sir Toby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you:
You drew your sword upon me without cause;
But I bespoke you fair, and hurt you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me: I
think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
Here comes Sir Toby halting; you shall hear more:
but if he had not been in drink, he would have
tickled you othergates than he did.
STAGEDIR: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and Clown

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: How now, gentleman! how is't with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: That's all one: has hurt me, and there's the end
on't. Sot, didst see Dick surgeon, sot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: O, he's drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone; his eyes
were set at eight i' the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Then he's a rogue, and a passy measures panyn: I
hate a drunken rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW
LINE: I'll help you, Sir Toby, because well be dressed together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIR TOBY BELCH
LINE: Will you help? an ass-head and a coxcomb and a
knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be look'd to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman:
But, had it been the brother of my blood,
I must have done no less with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that
I do perceive it hath offended you:
Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows
We made each other but so late ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A natural perspective, that is and is not!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
How have the hours rack'd and tortured me,
Since I have lost thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: Sebastian are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Fear'st thou that, Antonio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONIO
LINE: How have you made division of yourself?
An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Most wonderful!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature,
Of here and every where. I had a sister,
Whom the blind waves and surges have devour'd.
Of charity, what kin are you to me?
What countryman? what name? what parentage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father;
Such a Sebastian was my brother too,
So went he suited to his watery tomb:
If spirits can assume both form and suit
You come to fright us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: A spirit I am indeed;
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
I should my tears let fall upon your cheek,
And say 'Thrice-welcome, drowned Viola!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: My father had a mole upon his brow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: And so had mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had number'd thirteen years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN
LINE: O, that record is lively in my soul!
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurp'd attire,
Do not embrace me till each circumstance
Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
That I am Viola: which to confirm,
I'll bring you to a captain in this town,
Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
I was preserved to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SEBASTIAN

LINE.__text: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook:

LINE: But nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid;
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived,
You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Be not amazed; right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,
I shall have share in this most happy wreck.
Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: And all those sayings will I overswear;
And those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Give me thy hand;
And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIOLA
LINE: The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid's garments: he upon some action
Is now in durance, at Malvolio's suit,
A gentleman, and follower of my lady's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither:
And yet, alas, now I remember me,
They say, poor gentleman, he's much distract.
A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish'd his.
How does he, sirrah?
STAGEDIR: Re-enter Clown with a letter, and FABIAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the staves's end as
well as a man in his case may do: has here writ a
letter to you; I should have given't you to-day
morning, but as a madman's epistles are no gospels,
so it skills not much when they are delivered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Open't, and read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers
the madman.
'By the Lord, madam,'--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: How now! art thou mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: No, madam, I do but read madness: an your ladyship
will have it as it ought to be, you must allow Vox.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: So I do, madonna; but to read his right wits is to
read thus: therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Read it you, sirrah.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN

LINE.__text: 'By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the

LINE: world shall know it: though you have put me into
darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over
me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as
your ladyship. I have your own letter that induced
me to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt
not but to do myself much right, or you much shame.
Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little
unthought of and speak out of my injury.
THE MADLY-USED MALVOLIO.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Did he write this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Ay, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: This savours not much of distraction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: See him deliver'd, Fabian; bring him hither.
My lord so please you, these things further
thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown the alliance on't, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
Your master quits you; and for your service done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you call'd me master for so long,
Here is my hand: you shall from this time be
Your master's mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: A sister! you are she.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Is this the madman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Have I, Malvolio? no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is your hand:
Write from it, if you can, in hand or phrase;
Or say 'tis not your seal, nor your invention:
You can say none of this: well, grant it then
And tell me, in the modesty of honour,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favour,
Bade me come smiling and cross-garter'd to you,
To put on yellow stockings and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And, acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffer'd me to be imprison'd,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e'er invention play'd on? tell me why.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though, I confess, much like the character
But out of question 'tis Maria's hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad; then camest in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presupposed
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content:
This practise hath most shrewdly pass'd upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FABIAN
LINE: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wonder'd at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceived against him: Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby's great importance;
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow'd,
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge;
If that the injuries be justly weigh'd
That have on both sides pass'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: Why, 'some are born great, some achieve greatness,
and some have greatness thrown upon them.' I was
one, sir, in this interlude; one Sir Topas, sir; but
that's all one. 'By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.'
But do you remember? 'Madam, why laugh you at such
a barren rascal? an you smile not, he's gagged:'
and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MALVOLIO
LINE: I'll be revenged on the whole pack of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OLIVIA
LINE: He hath been most notoriously abused.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUKE ORSINO
LINE: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace:
He hath not told us of the captain yet:
When that is known and golden time convents,
A solemn combination shall be made
Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario, come;
For so you shall be, while you are a man;
But when in other habits you are seen,
Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown
LINE: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man's estate,
With hey, ho, &c.
'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came, alas! to wive,
With hey, ho, &c.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey, ho, &c.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, &c.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey, ho, &c.
But that's all one, our play is done,
And we'll strive to please you every day.
